title: Staging Systems: TNM Classification (AJCC/UICC)
summary: Detailed guide to the TNM classification system for cancer staging, including components, interpretation, and clinical applications.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: The TNM classification system, developed jointly by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC), is the global standard for anatomic cancer staging.
The TNM system facilitates consistent cancer staging across clinical settings, research protocols, and cancer registries worldwide.

rows: Size and local extent of the primary tumor
T1: ≤2 cm, T4: chest wall or skin invasion
N2: fixed axillary nodes or internal mammary nodes
M1: lung, bone, liver, or nonregional node metastasis

content.text: Each component is scored independently and then grouped into stage categories I–IV based on tumor-specific algorithms.
The T classification varies by cancer type but generally follows:

rows: Increasing tumor size and/or local invasion
Specific invasion patterns (e.g., T4d = inflammatory breast cancer)

items: T4: Any size with skin/chest wall involvement [See full AMBOSS table → Breast Cancer TNM](https://www.amboss.com/us/knowledge/breast-cancer?utm_medium=chatgpt-plugin&utm_source=chatgpt)
N1: Mobile level I–II axillary nodes

content.text: Example (Melanoma): Presence of microsatellitosis or in-transit metastases affects the N stage [See Melanoma Staging Details](https://www.amboss.com/us/knowledge/melanoma?utm_medium=chatgpt-plugin&utm_source=chatgpt)

items: Lung Cancer M1a: Tumor in contralateral lung lobe
M1 includes nonregional nodes (e.g., cervical nodes in breast cancer)

rows: Larger tumors or limited nodal spread

items: Gastric: T1N0M0 = Stage IA [See Gastric Cancer Staging](https://www.amboss.com/us/knowledge/gastric-cancer?utm_medium=chatgpt-plugin&utm_source=chatgpt)

content.text: The TNM classification system remains the backbone of solid tumor staging. It has evolved from a purely anatomical tool to a biologically informed, context-aware framework that continues to guide prognosis, therapy, and research worldwide.
Mastery of TNM staging is essential for oncologists, surgeons, pathologists, and all members of the multidisciplinary cancer care team.
